head.title: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering; Cat-and-Mouse Game

hedline.hl1: Time to End Iraqis' Suffering; Cat-and-Mouse Game

abstract.p: Matthew E Kaplan letter, commenting on Nov 16 article, says US must force Iraq to comply with United Nations weapons inspections without any further interruption

block.p: Your Nov. 16 front-page article ''Clinton Accepts Iraq's Promise to Allow Weapons Inspections'' caused me to wonder whether the United States and the United Nations intend to insure that Saddam Hussein's arsenal is devoid of all weapons of mass destruction or, as seems to be the case, to pay lip service to the principles for which the Persian Gulf war was fought. Countries cannot be trusted to implement the terms of an agreement on the honor code.

Your Nov. 16 front-page article ''Clinton Accepts Iraq's Promise to Allow Weapons Inspections'' caused me to wonder whether the United States and the United Nations intend to insure that Saddam Hussein's arsenal is devoid of all weapons of mass destruction or, as seems to be the case, to pay lip service to the principles for which the Persian Gulf war was fought. Countries cannot be trusted to implement the terms of an agreement on the honor code.

The United States must force Iraq to comply with United Nations weapons inspections without any further interruption, or it must forgo the entire process, allow the sanctions against Iraq to end and accept the fact that Mr. Hussein continues to possess a multitude of deadly weapons. The former is the only prudent course of action; however, our present state of enforcement will certainly result in the latter. The game of cat and mouse must end.
MATTHEW E. KAPLAN New York, Nov. 16, 1998
